pageProps.contentHtml:
representation theory

Determine the character table of S4S_4S4​, the symmetric group on 444 letters. Justify your answer.
Solution.

Recall that S4S_4S4​ has 555 conjugacy classes. Thus, by Artin-Wedderburn and algebraic closure of C\CC, we have

CS4≃Mn1(C)×⋯×Mn5(C)\C S_4 \simeq M_{n_1}\p{\C} \times \cdots \times M_{n_5}\p{\C}CS4​≃Mn1​​(C)×⋯×Mn5​​(C)

with n1≤⋯≤n4n_1 \leq \cdots \leq n_4n1​≤⋯≤n4​ and 24=∣S4∣=n12+⋯+n5224 = \abs{S_4} = n_1^2 + \cdots + n_5^224=∣S4​∣=n12​+⋯+n52​. If ni≤2n_i \leq 2ni​≤2 for each iii, then n12+⋯+n52≤20<24n_1^2 + \cdots + n_5^2 \leq 20 < 24n12​+⋯+n52​≤20<24, so at least one nin_ini​ is larger than 222, say n5n_5n5​. Note that n5≤4n_5 \leq 4n5​≤4, since 52>245^2 > 2452>24, so there are two possibilities for n5n_5n5​: if n5=4n_5 = 4n5​=4, then we have n12+⋯+n42=24−16=8n_1^2 + \cdots + n_4^2 = 24 - 16 = 8n12​+⋯+n42​=24−16=8. At least one of these must be larger than 111, so n4=2n_4 = 2n4​=2, but then we'd have n12+n22+n32=4n_1^2 + n_2^2 + n_3^2 = 4n12​+n22​+n32​=4 so this case isn't possible.

If n5=3n_5 = 3n5​=3, then we have n12+⋯+n42=24−9=15n_1^2 + \cdots + n_4^2 = 24 - 9 = 15n12​+⋯+n42​=24−9=15. By quickly checking the possibilities, we see n4=2n_4 = 2n4​=2 isn't possible, so n4=3n_4 = 3n4​=3 also. From here, we see that we have n1=n2=1n_1 = n_2 = 1n1​=n2​=1, n3=2n_3 = 2n3​=2, n4=n5=3n_4 = n_5 = 3n4​=n5​=3. Thus, our character table is of the form

id⁡(1,2)(1,2)(3,4)(1,2,3)(1,2,3,4)χ111111χ21χ32χ43χ53\begin{array}{cccccc} & \id & \p{1, 2} & \p{1, 2}\p{3, 4} & \p{1, 2, 3} & \p{1, 2, 3, 4} \\\hline \chi_1 & 1 & 1 & 1 & 1 & 1 \\ \chi_2 & 1 \\ \chi_3 & 2 \\ \chi_4 & 3 \\ \chi_5 & 3 \\\hline \end{array}χ1​χ2​χ3​χ4​χ5​​id11233​(1,2)1(1,2)(3,4)1(1,2,3)1(1,2,3,4)1​

where χi\chi_iχi​ is a character (with χ1\chi_1χ1​ the trivial character).

Recall the sign homomorphism S4→{±1}S_4 \to \set{\pm 1}S4​→{±1}, which gives a 111-dimensional character. This gives the row

id⁡(1,2)(1,2)(3,4)(1,2,3)(1,2,3,4)χ21−111−1\begin{array}{cccccc} & \id & \p{1, 2} & \p{1, 2}\p{3, 4} & \p{1, 2, 3} & \p{1, 2, 3, 4} \\\hline \chi_2 & 1 & -1 & 1 & 1 & -1 \\\hline \end{array}χ2​​id1​(1,2)−1​(1,2)(3,4)1​(1,2,3)1​(1,2,3,4)−1​​

We also have a (reducible) representation ρ\rhoρ of S4S_4S4​ in C4\C^4C4 by sending each permutation to its corresponding permutation matrix. This representation is reducible: let V=span⁡{e1+e2+e3+e4}V = \span\set{e_1 + e_2 + e_3 + e_4}V=span{e1​+e2​+e3​+e4​} and decompose C4≃V⊕WC^4 \simeq V \oplus WC4≃V⊕W where WWW is the orthogonal complement to VVV. Note that ρ∣V\restr{\rho}{V}ρ∣V​ is the trivial representation and that W=span⁡{e1−e2,e1−e3,e1−e4}W = \span\set{e_1 - e_2, e_1 - e_3, e_1 - e_4}W=span{e1​−e2​,e1​−e3​,e1​−e4​}.

Let χ4=ρ∣W\chi_4 = \restr{\rho}{W}χ4​=ρ∣W​. Then

χ3(id⁡)=3χ3((1,2))=χ3((2,3))=1χ3((1,2)(3,4))=χ3((1,4)(2,3))=−1χ3((1,2,3))=χ3((2,3,4))=0χ3((1,2,3,4))=−1\begin{aligned} \chi_3\p{\id} &= 3 \\ \chi_3\p{\p{1, 2}} &= \chi_3\p{\p{2, 3}} = 1 \\ \chi_3\p{\p{1, 2}\p{3, 4}} &= \chi_3\p{\p{1, 4}\p{2, 3}} = -1 \\ \chi_3\p{\p{1, 2, 3}} &= \chi_3\p{\p{2, 3, 4}} = 0 \\ \chi_3\p{\p{1, 2, 3, 4}} &= -1 \end{aligned}χ3​(id)χ3​((1,2))χ3​((1,2)(3,4))χ3​((1,2,3))χ3​((1,2,3,4))​=3=χ3​((2,3))=1=χ3​((1,4)(2,3))=−1=χ3​((2,3,4))=0=−1​

and

⟨χ4,χ4⟩=124(1⋅32+6⋅1+8⋅0+6⋅1+3⋅1)=1,\inner{\chi_4, \chi_4} = \frac{1}{24} \p{1 \cdot 3^2 + 6 \cdot 1 + 8 \cdot 0 + 6 \cdot 1 + 3 \cdot 1} = 1,⟨χ4​,χ4​⟩=241​(1⋅32+6⋅1+8⋅0+6⋅1+3⋅1)=1,

so χ4\chi_4χ4​ is actually an irreducible 333-dimensional representation. This also gives χ5\chi_5χ5​, since χ2χ4\chi_2\chi_4χ2​χ4​ is another character. We now have the table

id⁡(1,2)(1,2)(3,4)(1,2,3)(1,2,3,4)χ111111χ21−111−1χ32abcdχ431−10−1χ53−1−101\begin{array}{cccccc} & \id & \p{1, 2} & \p{1, 2}\p{3, 4} & \p{1, 2, 3} & \p{1, 2, 3, 4} \\\hline \chi_1 & 1 & 1 & 1 & 1 & 1 \\ \chi_2 & 1 & -1 & 1 & 1 & -1 \\ \chi_3 & 2 & a & b & c & d \\ \chi_4 & 3 & 1 & -1 & 0 & -1 \\ \chi_5 & 3 & -1 & -1 & 0 & 1 \\\hline \end{array}χ1​χ2​χ3​χ4​χ5​​id11233​(1,2)1−1a1−1​(1,2)(3,4)11b−1−1​(1,2,3)11c00​(1,2,3,4)1−1d−11​​

Finally, to complete the table, we just need to use the orthogonality relations. Columns 111 and 222 give 2a=02a = 02a=0, so a=0a = 0a=0; columns 111 and 333 give 2+2b−6=02 + 2b - 6 = 02+2b−6=0, so b=2b = 2b=2; columns 111 and 444 give 2+2c=02 + 2c = 02+2c=0, so c=−1c = -1c=−1; and columns 111 and 555 give 2d=02d = 02d=0, so d=0d = 0d=0. Thus, the character table is

id⁡(1,2)(1,2)(3,4)(1,2,3)(1,2,3,4)χ111111χ21−111−1χ3202−10χ431−10−1χ53−1−101\begin{array}{cccccc} & \id & \p{1, 2} & \p{1, 2}\p{3, 4} & \p{1, 2, 3} & \p{1, 2, 3, 4} \\\hline \chi_1 & 1 & 1 & 1 & 1 & 1 \\ \chi_2 & 1 & -1 & 1 & 1 & -1 \\ \chi_3 & 2 & 0 & 2 & -1 & 0 \\ \chi_4 & 3 & 1 & -1 & 0 & -1 \\ \chi_5 & 3 & -1 & -1 & 0 & 1 \\\hline \end{array}χ1​χ2​χ3​χ4​χ5​​id11233​(1,2)1−101−1​(1,2)(3,4)112−1−1​(1,2,3)11−100​(1,2,3,4)1−10−11​​
